ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION

RESIGNATION OF DOCTORS
(Particulars)


    1. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for Health and Home Affairs (a) how many doctors resigned from the service between 1st January, 1974 and 28th February, 1975, and if he is aware of any further resignations in the offing: and (b) what action has been initiated to replace them and what steps have been taken to ensure that adequate

Column: 568

medical attention is afforded to patients in the hospitals.

    The Minister for Health and Home Affairs (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, between 1st January, 1974, and 28th February, 1975, 98 doctors resigned from the service. Eighty-three resigned in 1974 and 15 in the first two months of 1975.

    I am not aware of any further resignations in the offing. In the last two years most resignations of doctors took place at the beginning of the year, that is, after they have received their 13th month payment in December.

Column: 569



    Of the 98 doctors who resigned, 69 were without higher qualifications, 26 possessed higher qualifications and two were consultants.

    Out of the 83 doctors who resigned in 1974, 57 or 73% were young doctors with less than four years' service. Eight were experienced doctors with more than ten years' service.

    However, in 1974 and the first two months of 1975, 129 doctors including 17 with higher qualifications joined the service. There was, therefore, a net gain of 31 doctors.

    Doctors of consultant rank in service in 1974 were 80, compared to 65 in 1973, and 48 in 1970. There were 91 Senior Registrars in 1974, compared to 40 in 1970. There were 60 medical officers with higher qualifications in 1974, compared to 36 in 1970. The quality of the medical services has not suffered. In fact, there have been more consultants, and doctors with higher qualifications in service and with better facilities and equipment.

    There are now about 100 vacancies in the establishment for doctors. However, at any time about 40 National Service doctors are working in the hospitals.

    The problem is to recruit more young doctors to lessen the workload on the existing staff because of the vacancies, as well as to man our expanding medical services. There is also the problem of retaining them in the service and reducing the turnover of doctors. A number of positive steps have been taken to meet the problem. They are:

     1. Accelerated Promotion Opportunities

    Promotions have now been made on merit. They are no longer limited to the number of higher posts available in the establishment. Promotion exercises have been held twice a year.

    2. More Training Awards And Fellowships.

    Under a Medical Traineeship Scheme young doctors who want to become

Column: 570

specialists can apply and be selected as trainee designates. They are given guidance and facilities to acquire higher qualifications from our School of Postgraduate Studies. At present there are 62 trainee designates under the Scheme. A selection exercise is now being conducted for another batch of more than 50 candidates. Awards and fellowship for courses of study as well as for practical training abroad have been given liberally. At present there are 14 Government doctors studying abroad for specialist qualifications. Another 18 have been selected to go abroad on scholarship.

    3. Revision of Specialist Allowance.

    Specialist allowance payable to doctors with higher qualifications has been improved since 1969. The allowance ranges from $100 to $1,000 per month according to the grade of the officer. This specialist allowance is not payable to other professional officers in the Civil Service.

    Doctors without higher qualifications also have had increases in remuneration by revisions of salary, National Wages Council Awards and 13th month payments. For example, a medical officer after the second year of service will now receive an all-in salary of $1,588.50 per month, compared to $1,200 in 1972.

    However, my Ministry is very much aware of the difficulties young Government doctors have in finding suitable accommodation. My Ministry has therefore planned to build three 28-storey blocks comprising a total of 264 five-room apartment units as quarters for Government doctors. These three blocks will be part of the development of the Singapore General Hospital at Outram Road.

    Meanwhile, my Ministry is negotiating an offer by the Port of Singapore Authority to let out or sell to our doctors apartments being built at Spottiswoode Park.

    Preferential condition for housing is a better way of attracting and retaining doctors in the service than an outright increase in salary.

    Mr Ho See Beng (Bras Basah)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, when the doctors tendered their resignations, did the Personnel officer in the Ministry of Health try to persuade them to stay and so retain these doctors? Or did the officer just say, "If you want to resign, you can resign. There are others, who want to join the service." I would like to know if there were such instances.

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Sir, we do not take such an attitude. The point is that we try our best to retain our doctors. Once the doctors have made up their mind to resign, they will of course resign because they must have made other arrangements. But we do try to find out what are the reasons behind their resignations and see if there is anything possible we can do to prevent them from resigning. We have tried. But, as I have said in my reply, one of the reasons which induce young doctors to resign is their difficulty in finding suitable accommodation because of higher rentals. That is the reason why my Ministry has planned to build three 28-storey blocks of five-room apartments as quarters for Government doctors.

    The Member for Bras Basah should not be under the impression that the Ministry's attitude is that they should resign if they want to. The point is that if they insist on resigning, there is very little we can do about it. But everything has been done to encourage them to remain in service.

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead AAA 1003.

    Sir, the Ministry of Communications has the very onerous task of reorganising our public transport system. The Ministry also has to solve the growing congestion on our roads as well as to streamline our traffic system in line with industrial and commercial developments for the benefit of our people. This is a very important task and I hope the reorganisation of the public transport system will be successful. Sir, I would like to raise three questions. First, it is about the reorganisation of the public transport system, which has already been in operation for two or three years. There has been some progress made but, according to the public, progress has been very slow. The reorganisation includes the introduction of bus lanes, pedestrian walks and the restriction of traffic flow into the CBD. The purpose of these measures is, of course, to improve travel by public transport. Since the reorganisatiop. I would like to know whether there has been any marked or radical improvement.

    According to what I hear, improvement has been very slight because at peak hours traffic is still very congested. Moreover, we can see buses break down along the road. The buses also emit obnoxious smoke and the condition inside the bus leaves much room for improvement. In regard to bus lanes and the siting of bus stops there are many shortcomings which need to be remedied. And where the road is too narrow, say, Robinson Road, at about 5.00 p.m, everyday the buses are parked along the bus lane by the tens. In the end, the bus lane is turned into a bus terminal where buses are parked. So you find that all the buses are squeezed together in a queue, one after the other, thus causing congestion of all the other vehicles on the road.

in the House about the Mass Rapid Transit system that was going to be introduced in 1980. including the plan for an underground rail system. What progress has been made in respect of this plan, and whether he can give a detailed account to this House.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Mr Speaker. Sir, last year, the Minister `pledged to alleviate the shocking conditions of the bus transport system in Singapore. I must congratulate the Minister this year, for there has been a tremendous improvement in our mass transport system.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Hear, hear!

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: However, there are a few anomalies, which I hope the Minister will do his best to overcome. Certain bus services are very irregular, particularly those serving in the rural areas. As an example, service 190 from Shenton Way to Bukit Merah particularly seems to be completely absent from 6.30 p.m, to 7.30 p.m. What I understand is that bus drivers and conductors running this service go out for their meal breaks during this hour and thus keep the poor commuters waiting.

    Furthermore, I understand that some bus drivers use to speed along the road and reach their terminus much' earlier than the scheduled times, and no one questions them for arriving early. I wonder whether the SBS is seriously checking on the scheduled stops at all

Column: 575

the bus stops along the route to ensure that the service is being run frequently and efficiently.

    The maintenance of buses seems to be rather poor. Even if the engine is m a working condition, is the bus checked to ensure that other service facilities are functioning effectively? There have been instances when windows as well as ventilators cannot be closed during a shower. In these cases it rains not only outside but also inside the buses. On this matter, may I ask the Minister what is the Registry of Vehicles doing about checking the condition of the buses, and how frequently is a bus checked for serviceability? Is a certificate of fitness issued by the ROV for each bus? In this respect, I must say that the Scheme B buses are far better in cleanliness, comfort, courtesy and service to the commuters.

    I also observe that at the SBS maintenance centres, the spare parts are left all over the place. This encourages theft as spare parts are valuable to some people. Can something be done about this mess? They must understand that they pay a very high price for these parts and without any proper enclosures or security measures they are bound to be stolen.

    Rudeness on the part of conductors and drivers has been reduced remarkably. A good job done I must say. However, bus drivers still have to improve their standard of driving. Speeding is still a common offence among the drivers. There is a lot of publicity when new buses are commissioned on the roads every month. But hardly any publicity is given to the number of buses that are laid off through breakdowns and the many major accidents caused by some of the reckless SBS drivers. I think the Minister will notice this when he drives to his office to see whether this is true. If the same number or more buses are taken off the road for these reasons, then additions of new buses to the services are completely nullified. I feel we have to import ready-made buses from overseas by the hundreds, and we have

to grant a loan to SBS for this on a long term basis to enable them to recover the cost of these buses. In this way probably our transport problems will be solved. Many people are willing to give up their cars only if the bus service is more efficient and if there are sufficient bus shelters to protect them from the weather.

    The display board on the bus showing the service number and the route needs some improvement. In this respect too the Scheme B service buses are far ahead of the SBS. It is pointless to display only the service number and its destination, because commuters would also like to know the various roads along the service route. Surely, this is not asking too much. A small display board showing the main roads along the route can go a long way to help the travelling public.

    What is being done about keeping the termini of the buses clean and safe? Many of the terminals are covered with traces of dirty black oil spills which arc quite often a source of danger. particularly on rainy days. The terminals at Yio Chu Kang Road for service 73 and Upper Thomson Road for service 165 are some examples.

    The new buses are supposed to have a new type of seat made of fibre-glass. I presume. Unfortunately, this type does not last very long. Most of these seats in the buses are in poor condition. If one is not careful, one is going to receive nasty cuts from a damaged seat. Can something be done to replace these seats with more durable material? The SBS should not only look into the question of quantity but also on the quality of buses.

    At some terminals there is no indication which particular bus is going to move out first. The conductors, drivers and time-keepers are no help either. Surely the parking of buses at terminals could be arranged in such a way that the bus at one end will always leave first. This will not keep the commuters guessing. There arc occasions when commuters board a stationary bus at the terminal but they are not told that that

Column: 577

bus is either spoilt or will not be the first to leave. Though so many drivers, conductors and timekeepers are present, they just look at the commuters. This goes on very frequently at the terminal point near the Singapore General Hospital. Can something be done about it?

    Sir, I would also like to ask if the Minister will consider extending the bus service, which now ends at Shenton Way, to serve Keppel Road ending after the Telok Blangah housing estate. This will help the many port workers who have to take this route. Furthermore a bus service should also be proposed from Cantonment Road to Keppel Road/Telok Blangah Road for port workers.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, at peak hours from 4.00 p.m. to 6.00 p.m. the buses coming from the terminal at Shenton Way are always full. But along the way, from Robinson Road to the junction of Market Street all the bus stops are crowded, and the people have to wait for hours. There must be a certain system of re-routing the buses, say, certain buses should be routed from the terminals, certain buses from Market Street, certain buses from the esplanade, and so on. But I am not saying anything more. The Hon. Minister must understand the situation. In the days of the Singapore Traction Company, when their superintendents knew that the commuters were waiting in crowds, they said, "All right, get one bus down from somewhere and bring it here." Or on inspection, they would say. "Bring this service here and tell everybody that this bus is going to Katong," or "This bus is going to Serangoon." Why cannot the SBS use that system? "I am giving more buses" - what is the use of giving more buses? The buses at the terminals are already full and commuters along the route have to wait for hours.

3.00 p.m.

    The Minister will notice this if he passes along these roads up to High Street at 5 o'clock. There are more new

buses but they are still insufficient because they are always full during peak hours. Therefore, SBS has to arrange a way so that the passengers can get the bus at the proper time to reach home early. But now they leave office at 5 o'clock and reach home at 7 o'clock. They work eight hours but they are out for 12 hours. Something must be done and the very minor matters must be considered, or they will become a bad problem. I ask the Minister to go round these routes at 5 o'clock one day and see what is happening.

    Mr Cheong Yuen Chee (Toa Payoh):Sir, it has always been recognised that there is a shortage of land for development in Singapore. I believe that there is even a special committee to ensure that any available vacant land is properly utilised, that is, with maximum economic benefit. The Central Business District scheme has taken up valuable land which can be utilised for other essential projects like recreational parks and public housing. Notwithstanding the costs involved in the construction of the numerous fringe area-car parks, the valuable land so acquired is in use only for part of the day. During the night these car parks will be left vacant. Millions of dollars will be spent in the construction of these fringe area car parks, the overhead signboards and the necessary checkpoints. The only consolation in this scheme is that job opportunities will be created. Perhaps the Ministry of Communications hopes to recover all or part of the cost from the fees collected arising out of this scheme for motorists.

    It is regretted that the CBD scheme is to be introduced at a time when the public transport system has not yet shown any significant improvement. Commuters have still to wait for long hours for the buses. I concede that there is some improvement in the conduct of bus crews. My congratulations to the men who are responsible for raising the morale of the bus workers and putting some semblance of efficient management in the SBS.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in my opinion the CBD scheme when implemented will have more disadvantages than advantages. For example, the Ministry of communications was mainly instrumental in the successful elimination of pirate taxis from our roads. With the CBD scheme, there is nothing to prevent an enterprising person to purchase a car, which is now at rock-bottom prices, round up four or five persons at great personal risk to the passengers and enter the CBD, thus making a profit; all with the blessings of the Ministry of Communications. What is to prevent employers from reimbursing their executive and managerial staff for the area licence fees imposed? Professionals similarly will have no problem in paying the fees as they can pass this burden on to their clients. Salesmen and bill collectors will make the claims to their respective units for reimbursement. With increased costs, the employers will certainly add this on to the cost of goods and services. In the end, the poor consumers suffer through such further inflation; also -with the blessings of the Ministry of communications.

    Sir, if there is no restriction on the number of vehicles that is allowed to enter the CBD, and coupled with the aforementioned loopholes, how can we hope to relieve traffic congestion? The question is: is it worthwhile to spend so much money on the CBD scheme only to derive so little benefit from it? Surely there are other alternative measures, like prohibiting cars with certain licence numbers from entering the CBD area at specified times of the day. For example, cars with licence numbers ending with 1 and 2 may be prohibited from entering the CBD on Mondays between certain hours, and so on. In this way, every- motorist has to refrain entry into the CBD for a few hours a week, and there will be a' definite reduction in vehicular traffic within the CBD. I do not think that, the alternative measures proposed will in any way

involve extensive enforcement or the engagement of an army of inspectors to check on erring motorists. Stiff penalties together with the points demerit system will be a sufficient deterrent.

    The anti-litter campaign succeeded not because there was an army of health inspectors swarming all over the place hut because of strict enforcement and stiff penalties. The present plan tends to favour those who can afford or who have the means to recover the cost of the licence fees and increased car park charges.' I do not think it will relieve traffic congestion within the CBD. Assuming that the proposed plan will succeed, it will inevitably transfer traffic congestion to other parts of the city during peak hours.

    But the Member for Sembawang raised two other points which I think I can answer now. He mentioned about the progress of the Mass Transit Study. Here again, it comes under amendment (9)* (* The amendment reads as follows:(9) That the sum to be allocated for Head 0 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead AAA 8101.) and if he wilt be patient enough to wait, we can give him the answer then. But he did mention about the Road Transport Action Committee's policies which are not well received and inquired whether this came within the White Paper on the Reorganisation of the Motor Transport Service of Singapore. I would like to bring to his notice that this White Paper was a three-year plan for the period 1970-73. So it has nothing to do with the Road Transport Action Committee of five Permanent Secretaries, which was appointed in October 1973 after the recommendations of the White Paper have already been more or less accomplished, nor has it anything to do with the follow-up of the recommendations in the White Paper. These are new policies subsequent to the publication of the White Paper.

    Sir, I beg to differ with the Member that the policies are not well received. If at all they are not popular measures, that I agree. But the Government has to be responsible. It has got to make unpopular decisions and hard decisions in, order to resolve difficult problems.

    I can, however, reply more fully to the Member for Toa Payoh's reservations over the success of the schemes which we intend to implement to reduce traffic congestion in the Central Business District. So far, about $7 million has been committed to implement the two traffic management schemes, namely, the park-and-ride and the area licensing schemes. This amount is for the con-

Column: 582

struction of 12 fringe area car parks, parking kiosks at these car parks, provision of new bus shelters, provision of daily area licence sale booths and the erection of overhead gantry signs which are now all, over Singapore, as well as new road direction signs. Contrary to what the Member for Toa Payoh says, we expect a significant improvement in traffic conditions `within the CBD following the introduction of these two traffic management measures.

    Various alternative methods of reducing the number of vehicles entering the CBD during the peak periods have been examined before the park-and-ride and the area licensing schemes were selected as being the most appropriate and effective measures for Singapore. The Member has indicated one method and there are also other methods which ,have been suggested, like - allowing vehicles with registration numbers ending in odd numbers entering the CBD on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays, and those ending in even numbers on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays.

3.15 p.m.

    In fact, the Member for Toa Payoh did put in a paper and it was studied by the Road Transport Action Committee. Unfortunately we have to tell him that though his idea sounds very simple to operate, there are three major serious difficulties when it comes to implementation. Firstly, it will place an automatic restriction of almost one half of the car motoring public and, with at least 140,000 cars registered in Singapore, this means that 70,000 car owners will not be able to use those `cars: This is much too high a level of restriction on the movement of private cars for the time being. Secondly, it does not provide such affected motorists with a

Column: 583

genuine need or in an emergency to drive into the city because they are not supposed to be on the road. So they just cannot move. Thirdly, such a scheme will affect all motorists whereas the proposed area licensing scheme is only aimed at restricting car drivers from entering the restricted zone and not elsewhere. The restricted zone is effective only for this two-hour period, from 7.30 a.m, to 9.30 a.m, in the morning, thus having a very minimum effect on business and commerce. There is no restriction of entry into the restricted zone outside these two peak hours in the morning. The area licensing scheme provides options to motorists who wish to continue to drive into the restricted zone. It is not just for the privileged few. They can come in at no extra cost provided the car has at least four passengers. In other words, we want to encourage them to form car pools. Another alternative for motorists would be to participate in the park and ride scheme, and those who choose this scheme would do so at an even much cheaper cost than what they would have to pay for seasonal parking in the city area, because the cost of such seasonal parking could be anything from $50 to $70 a month.

    A serious and conscientious effort must therefore be made by all car owners for a more rational use of our roads in the city. Motorists can choose to pay for the privilege to drive into the restricted area provided they pay a price, or help reduce traffic congestion through formation of car pools, or participate in the park and ride scheme, or opt for staggered hours outside the 7.30 a.m, to'9.30 a.m, time slot.
